title: A fibrinogen-related protein mediates the recognition of various bacteria and haemocyte phagocytosis in oyster Crassostrea gigas

affiliation.laboratory: Liaoning Key Laboratory of Marine Animal Immunology
Liaoning Key Laboratory of Marine Animal Immunology
Liaoning Key Laboratory of Marine Animal Immunology
Liaoning Key Laboratory of Marine Animal Immunology
Liaoning Key Laboratory of Marine Animal Immunology
Liaoning Key Laboratory of Marine Animal Immunology
Liaoning Key Laboratory of Marine Animal Immunology
Liaoning Key Laboratory of Marine Animal Immunology

abstract: The family of fibrinogen-related proteins (FREPs) is a group of proteins with fibrinogen-like (FBG) domains, which play important roles as pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) in the innate immune responses. In the present study, a fibrinogen-like protein was identified from the oyster Crassostrea gigas (defined as CgFREP1). The open reading frame of CgFREP1 was of 966 bp that encoded a predicted polypeptide of 321 amino acids comprising a signal peptide and a fibrinogen-like domain. The mRNA expression of CgFREP1 was detected in all the examined tissues. The recombinant CgFREP1 (rCgFREP1) displayed binding activities to lipopolysaccharide (LPS), mannose (MAN), as well as Gram-positive bacteria (Micrococcus luteus and Staphylococcus aureus) and Gram-negative bacteria (Vibrio splendidus and Escherichia coli). The rCgFREP1 displayed the agglutinating activity towards M. luteus, V. splendidus and E. coli in the presence of Ca 2+. rCgFREP1 was able to enhance the phagocytic activity of haemocytes towards V. splendidus, and exhibited binding activity to the CUB domain of CgMASPL-1. These results suggest that CgFREP1 not only serves as a PRR to recognize and agglutinate different bacteria but also mediates the haemocytes phagocytosis towards V. splendidus.

abstract.text: The family of fibrinogen-related proteins (FREPs) is a group of proteins with fibrinogen-like (FBG) domains, which play important roles as pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) in the innate immune responses. In the present study, a fibrinogen-like protein was identified from the oyster Crassostrea gigas (defined as CgFREP1). The open reading frame of CgFREP1 was of 966 bp that encoded a predicted polypeptide of 321 amino acids comprising a signal peptide and a fibrinogen-like domain. The mRNA expression of CgFREP1 was detected in all the examined tissues. The recombinant CgFREP1 (rCgFREP1) displayed binding activities to lipopolysaccharide (LPS), mannose (MAN), as well as Gram-positive bacteria (Micrococcus luteus and Staphylococcus aureus) and Gram-negative bacteria (Vibrio splendidus and Escherichia coli). The rCgFREP1 displayed the agglutinating activity towards M. luteus, V. splendidus and E. coli in the presence of Ca 2+. rCgFREP1 was able to enhance the phagocytic activity of haemocytes towards V. splendidus, and exhibited binding activity to the CUB domain of CgMASPL-1. These results suggest that CgFREP1 not only serves as a PRR to recognize and agglutinate different bacteria but also mediates the haemocytes phagocytosis towards V. splendidus.

body_text.text: Fibrinogen-related proteins (FREPs) are a family of proteins characterized by the presence of fibrinogen-like (FBG) domains [1] , which act as pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) and play important roles in the activation of complement system in mammals [2, 3] . Various FREPs have been so far identified in vertebrates and invertebrates, such as ficolins, tenascins, tachylectins, angiopoietins, ixoderins, fibroleukin, and some other extracellular proteins [4] [5] [6] . The N-terminal of all the identified FREPs varies greatly, including collagen-like region [7] , immunoglobulin superfamily (IgSF) [8] and typical signal peptide [9] , while their C-terminal region is always the FBG domain [5, 6] .

The FBG domain in FREPs consists approximately of 200 amino acid residues, which is responsible for carbohydrate and pathogen binding [4, 10] . Ficolin is one of the well-known FREPs containing a collagen-like region and an FBG domain. In vertebrates, there are several ficolins identified from different species [11] [12] [13] . For example, three ficolins (L-ficolin/P35, H-ficolin and M-ficolin) have been identified from human [14] . There are two groups of ficolins, ficolin-A and ficolin-B, in mice, whose gene organization resembles of human L-ficolin and M-ficolin respectively [15] . Ficolin can specifically bind to various bacteria, pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs), and acts through the phagocytic pathway to enhance phagocytosis in vertebrates [10, [16] [17] [18] . Ficolin is also known as an important trigger to activate the lectin pathway of complement system by attaching mannose-binding lectin (MBL)-associated serine protease (MASPs) after recognizing the infectious agent [19] [20] [21] .

In recent years, numerous FREPs have been identified in invertebrates, such as echinoderms [22] , arthropods [23] , and molluscs [24] . There are 53 and 20 FREPs identified in Anopheles gambiae and Drosophila melanogaster, respectively [25, 26] . FREPs have also been found in some aquatic invertebrates, such as shrimp [27] [28] [29] , mussel [13] , oyster [9] , and scallop [30] [31] [32] , and they all contain the conserved FBG domain. Unlike Ficolin in vertebrates, FREPs in invertebrates lack of collagen-like domain [33] . For instance, AiFREP from scallop Argopecten irradians [30, 31] , ChFCN from oyster Crassostrea hongkongensis [9] and CgFREPs from oyster C. gigas [34] were found to lack the collagen-like domain in their N-terminus. FREPs in invertebrates all contain the FBG domain in their C-terminus. It is recently found that invertebrate FREPs can bind different bacteria and PAMPs. For instance, AgFBN9 in A. gambiae [25, 35] , MrFico1 and MrFico2 in Macrobrachium rosenbergii [36] , MnFico1 and MnFico2 in M. nipponense [37] , and BbFREP in Branchiostoma belcheri [38] exhibited strong binding activity to bacteria and PAMPs. The accumulating evidences have demonstrated that invertebrate FREPs also play important roles in bacteria agglutination and phagocytosis [31] . In A. irradians, AiFREP-2 exhibited agglutinating activity to Gram-negative bacteria Vibrio anguillarum and Gram-positive bacteria Staphylococcus aureus [30] . ChFCN in C. hongkongensis agglutinated Escherichia coli and enhanced the phagocytosis of haemocytes [9] , and PcFLP1 from Procambarus clarkii was able to inhibit bacterial replication and enhance bacterial elimination [29] . Moreover, the recombinant amphioxus FCN1 formed complexes with recombinant serine protease MASP1/3 and facilitated the activation of native C3 [14, 39] . Given the increasing interests in the origin and evolution of complement in invertebrates [40, 41] , the possible involvement of invertebrate FREPs in the activation of complement system remains concern.

The oyster C. gigas is an important mariculture bivalve worldwide, and an experimental model in the research of comparative immunology [24] . Because of the oyster living in the intertidal zones, they have to cope with a series of biotic threats and various of pathogens [42] . Immune recognition is the first step for host to discriminate pathogenic bacteria, in which PRRs are responsible for recognizing and binding PAMPs, and then triggering the signaling pathways to induce the transcription of a variety of immune effectors, such as antimicrobial peptides and inflammatory cytokines [43] . It is significant to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying immune recognition in the oyster. There are a large amounts of FREPs annotated in oyster genome, and most of them have been found significantly up-regulated after immune stimulation, suggesting their significance in the immune response of oysters [24, 34, 44] . In the present study, a FREP was identified from C. gigas (designated as CgFREP1) with the objectives to investigate its sequence feature and expression profile at the mRNA levels, determine the binding activity of CgFREP1 towards various PAMPs and bacteria, evaluate its function in agglutinating bacteria and inducing haemocytes phagocytosis, and clarify its possible involvement in antibacterial immunity of oysters.

The oysters C. gigas were collected from Dalian city, Liaoning Province, China. The oysters were acclimated in tank with aerated seawater before subsequent experiments. Adductor muscle, hepatopancreas, haemocytes, gills, mantle, gonad and labial palp were collected from nine adult oysters according to previous description [45] . The tissues and haemocytes from three oysters were pooled together as one sample, and there were three replicates for each tissue. All these samples were stored at − 80 • C after addition of 1 mL Trizol reagent (Invitrogen, USA) for subsequent RNA extraction [46] .

The physical and chemical parameters of CgFREP1 were predicted by ExPASy ProtParam (http://web.expasy.org/translate/). The CgFREP1 protein domain was predicted by SMART (http://smart.embl-heidelbe rg.de/). The N-glycosylation sites were predicted by the NetNGlyc 1.0 Server (http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/services/NetNGlyc/). The protein sequences of FREPs from different species were collected from the NCBI (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genbank/) for sequence alignment by Clustal W. A phylogenetic tree of FREPs was constructed with MEGA 6.0.
body_text.section: Sequence, homologous, and phylogenetic analysis of FREPs

body_text.text: The qRT-PCR with one pair of primers CgFREP1-RT-F and CgFREP1-RT-R (Table 1 ) was performed to detect the distribution of CgFREP1 mRNA in tissues and haemocytes [47] . The fragment of elongation factor (CgEF, GenBank accession No. NM_001305313), amplified with primers CgEF-RT-F and CgEF-RT-R (Table 1) , was used as internal control. The relative expression levels were determined by using the 2 − ΔΔCt method [47, 48] .
body_text.section: The qRT-PCR assay of CgFREP1 mRNA in tissues

body_text.text: The open reading frame (ORF) sequence of CgFREP1 (MW413321) was amplified by using the pair primers of CgFREP1-ExF and CgFREP1-ExR ( Table 1 ). The recombinant proteins were expressed and purified according to previous description [49] . Briefly, the PCR products were cut with BamH I and Xho I nucleases, gel purified, and ligated into the pET30a and pGEX4T-1 plasmid (Transgen, China) that included a His-tag (about 5.0 kDa) and GST-tag (about 25.0 kDa), respectively. The valid recombinant plasmid was extracted and transformed into E. coli Transetta (DE3) (TransGen Biotech, China). The positive transformant was grown with the culture to an OD 600 of 0.4-0.6, and isopropyl-β-D-1-Thiogalactopyranoside (IPTG) was added into the LB medium to induce the protein expression. The recombinant protein of pET30a-CgFREP1 with 6 × His-tag, and pGEX4T-1-CgFREP1 with GST-tag were purified and desalted by extensive dialysis. The purified protein was dialyzed against TBS and the concentration was quantified by BCA kit (Beyotime, China). The purified protein was concentrated and stored at − 80 • C. The rCgFREP1 with His-tag (designated as rHis-CgFREP1) was used for bacteria binding assay, PAMPs binding assay and phagocytosis assay, and the rCgFREP1 with GST-tag (designated as rGST-CgFREP1) was used for pull down assay and agglutination assay.
body_text.section: Recombinant expression and purification of CgFREP1

body_text.text: The first CUB domain of CgMASPL-1 (LOC105342011) was amplified by using the pair primers of CgMASPL-1-CUB1-ExF and CgMASPL-1-CUB1-ExR ( Table 1 ). The recombinant protein expression and purification of pET30a-CgMASPL-1-CUB1 was the same with above description.
body_text.section: Recombinant expression and purification of CgFREP1

body_text.text: Gram-positive bacteria (Micrococcus luteus and S. aureus), Gramnegative bacteria (V. splendidus and E. coli) were cultured and collected according to previous description [50] . The bacteria were suspended with 200 μL TBS and then incubated with 200 μL rHis-Cg-FREP1 (200 μg mL − 1 ) under slight rotation at room temperature for 3 h.
Sequences of the primers used in this study.

The bacteria combined with rHis-CgFREP1 proteins were centrifuged by centrifugation at 6000 × g for 5 min. After washed three times with TBS, the bacteria were resuspended in 80 μL TBS and 20 μL loading buffer for SDS-PAGE and then analyzed by western blot. The protein bands were visualized by using Super ELC Detection Reagent (Sigma-Aldrich, USA). The rTrx was set as negative control.

The PAMPs binding ability of rHis-CgFREP1 was measured by enzyme-linked immune sorbent assay (ELISA) according to previous report with some modification [30] . Briefly, lipopolysaccharide (LPS) from E. coli 055:B5 (Sigma-Aldrich, USA), peptidoglycan (PGN) from S. aureus (Sigma-Aldrich, USA) and mannose (MAN) from Yarrowia lipolytica (Sigma-Aldrich, USA) were dissolved to coat 96-well plate (Corning, USA). The wells were blocked with 3% BSA (Sangon Biotech, China) in TBST at 4 • C overnight. One hundred microliters of anti-His serum (diluted to 1:1000) was added to the well and incubated at 37 • C for 1 h. HRP Goat Anti-Mouse IgG (AB clonal Technology, China, diluted to 1:2000) was added to the well for incubation at 37 • C for 1 h. The same concentration of rTrx was used as control. After the last TBST washing, 100 μL of TMB Single-Component Substrate solution (Solarbio, China) was added and incubated at room temperature for 15 min. One hundred microliters of HCl (1 M) was added to the well to stop the reaction, and the absorbance was measured at 405 nm (TECAN, Switzerland). The wells with 100 μL of TBS were used as blank. Samples with P (sample)-B (blank)/N (negative)-B (blank) > 2.1 were considered as positive. Three replications were performed for each sample, and the data were presented as mean ± S.D. (n = 3).

The interaction between rGST-CgFREP1 and rCgMASPL-1-CUB1 was detected by the GST Pull-down assay according to the previously reported method with some modification [51] . Two hundred microliters of rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1 (200 μg mL -1 ) were incubated with 200 μL of Glutathione Agarose resin at 4 • C with gentle rocking for 1.5 h, and then incubated with 200 μL of rGST-CgFREP1 (200 μg mL -1 ) at 4 • C with gentle rocking for 1.5 h. The mixture was washed five times with TBS after each incubation. Finally, the eluted proteins were collected for testing by SDS-PAGE.

The microbial agglutination assay was performed as the previous report [30] . The fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) (Sigma, USA)-labeled S. aureus, M. luteus, V. splendidus and E. coli were suspended in TBS buffer at the final concentration of 1.0 × 10 9 cells mL -1 . Ten microliters of microbe suspension were added to 20 μL rGST-CgFREP1 (200 μg mL -1 ) and 10 mM CaCl 2 . The addition of same volume rGST (200 μg mL -1 ) was employed as the negative control. The cultures were incubated at room temperature for about 45 min, and cells were then observed by fluorescence microscope (ZEISS, Germany).

Phagocytosis assay was performed according to the previous description with modification [30, 52] . The bacteria V. splendidus were cultured and collected according to previous description [53] . The bacteria were incubated with FITC (0.1 mg mL -1 ) at 4 • C overnight with continuous gentle stirring. The haemocytes were collected from eighteen oysters, and three oysters were pooled together as one sample, with three replicates for each group. Twenty microliters of FITC labeled V. splendidus were incubated with 200 μL of rHis-CgFREP1 (200 μg mL -1 ) protein with slight rotation in dark at room temperature for 1 h. Two hundred microliters of haemocytes suspension was added into the mixture and incubated with slight rotation in dark at room temperature for 30 min. The capability of rHis-CgFREP1 to mediate phagocytosis was evaluated by FACSAria flow cytometry (BD, USA). With the same experimental method, the resuspended haemocytes were seeded on the glass slides and observed by using a fluorescence microscope (ZEISS, Germany) [53] . The phagocytic rate was calculated by the proportion of cells ingesting the bacteria in the total number of cells observed. About 100 cells were observed in each group for counting the phagocytic rate by fluorescence microscope which was shown as mean ± S.D. (n = 3). rTrx was used as negative control. Each experiment was repeated in triplicates.
body_text.section: Phagocytosis assay by using fluorescence microscope and FACSAria flow cytometry

body_text.text: All data were shown as mean ± S.D., and the two-sample Student's ttest was performed for the comparisons between groups. Multiple group comparisons were executed by one-way ANOVA and multiple

The ORF of CgFREP1 cDNA was of 966 bp, encoding a putative polypeptide of 321 amino acids (aa) with a predicted molecular mass of 36.8 kDa and theoretical isoelectric point of 7.56. There was a signal peptide (1-19 aa) and an FBG domain (107-320 aa) identified in CgFREP1. There were three potential glycosylation sites and one potential calcium-binding sites in the C-terminal FBG domain (Fig. 1A-B ).
body_text.section: Molecular characteristics, phylogenic relationship, and multiple sequence alignment of CgFREP1

body_text.text: Multiple sequence alignment showed that the amino acid sequences of FREPs were highly diversified in the N-terminus, while the C-terminal FBG domains were relatively conserved. The multiple sequence alignment analysis revealed that the FBG domains of FREPs contain conserved Ca 2+ binding sites (Fig. 2) . A phylogenetic tree was constructed using the neighbor-joining method by MEGA 6.0 to analyze the molecular evolutionary relationship of FREPs. The selected vertebrate and invertebrate FREPs were clearly separated into two branches in the phylogenetic tree, and CgFREP1 was clustered with FREPs in the invertebrate branch (Fig. 3) .
body_text.section: Molecular characteristics, phylogenic relationship, and multiple sequence alignment of CgFREP1

body_text.text: The mRNA expression level of CgFREP1 in different tissues was investigated by quantitative real-time PCR. The mRNA transcripts of CgFREP1 were ubiquitously detected in all the tested tissues, including adductor muscle, hepatopancreas, gills, mantle, gonad, labial palp, and haemocytes (Fig. 4) . The highest expression level of CgFREP1 was detected in labial palp, which was 11.00-fold higher (p < 0.05) than that in adductor muscle.
body_text.section: The mRNA expression pattern of CgFREP1 in different tissues

body_text.text: The bacterial binding activity of rHis-CgFREP1 was determined by western blot assay. After rHis-CgFREP1 was incubated with different bacteria, the distinct immune-precipitated bands were observed for the Gran-positive bacteria M. luteus and S. aureus, Gram-negative bacteria V. splendidus and E. coli. There was a distinct band observed on nitrocellulose membrane of the M. luteus, S. aureus, V. splendidus and E. coli group, respectively, with the addition of Ca 2+ or not. The band observed in Gram-positive bacteria (M. luteus and S. aureus) group was thicker than that in Gram-negative bacteria (V. splendidus and E. coli) group (Fig. 5A) . The raw data for western blot were shown in Fig. S1 . There was no band detected in the rTrx (control) group.
body_text.section: The bacterial binding activity of rCgFREP1

body_text.text: The binding capacity of rHis-CgFREP1 with different PAMPs was determined using ELISA assay. The rHis-CgFREP1 showed binding activity to MAN and LPS (Fig. 5B) . When the protein concentration of rHis-CgFREP1 increased from 18.75 μg mL -1 to 150 μg mL -1 , the P/N values of rHis-CgFREP1 to bind MAN increased from 1.62 to 2.38, and those to bind LPS increased from 2.04 to 2.73 (Fig. 5B) . The P/N value of rHis-CgFREP1 (at the concentration of 150 μg mL -1 ) to bind LPS and MAN was more than 2.1. The P/N value of rHis-CgFREP1 for binding PGN (at the concentration from 18.75 μg mL -1 to 150 μg mL -1 ) was less than 2.1, indicating that CgFREP1 displayed no binding activity to PGN. As a control, the P/N value was less than 2.1, indicating no binding affinity observed in the group of rTrx (data not shown).
body_text.section: The PAMPs binding activity of rCgFREP1

body_text.text: The first CUB domain of CgMASPL-1 (CgMASPL-1-CUB1) (Fig. 6A ) was recombinantly expressed. A clear band with a molecular weight of approximate 35.0 kDa (Fig. 6B, Lane 2-3) were observed by SDS-PAGE assay, which was consistent with the predicted molecular weight of rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1. CgFREP1 was recombinantly expressed in E. coli, and the recombinant proteins were purified with 6 × His tag and GST tag, respectively. A clear band with a molecular weight of approximate 60.0 kDa (Fig. 6C, Lane 2-3 ) and a band of 42.0 kDa (Fig. 6D, Lane 2-3) were observed by SDS-PAGE assay, which was consistent with the predicted The interaction between rGST-CgFREP1 and rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1 was tested by GST Pull-down assay. There was a band of rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1 observed after pulled down by rGST-CgFREP1 (Fig. 6E , Lane Elute) and a band of rGST-CgFREP1 observed after pulled down by rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1 (Fig. 6E, Lane Elute) . No bands were observed in wash solution lanes (Fig. 6E ).
body_text.section: The interaction between rGST-CgFREP1 and rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1

body_text.text: Microorganisms S. aureus, M. luteus, V. splendidus and E. coli were used to test the agglutination activity of rGST-CgFREP1. In the presence of Ca 2+ , rGST-CgFREP1 showed strong agglutination activity to M. luteus, V. splendidus and E. coli, but no agglutination activity was observed in S. aureus group (Fig. 7) . No agglutination of the microbes was observed in the rGST-CgFREP1 groups in the absence of Ca 2+ . In the groups of TBS and rGST, there was no agglutination of the microbes in the visual field in the absence of Ca 2+ .

The phagocytic activity of oyster haemocytes was quantified by using fluorescence microscope and flow cytometric analysis, respectively. Haemocytes were incubated with FITC-labeled V. splendidus and rHis-CgFREP1 to detect the haemocytes phagocytosis to V. splendidus. V. splendidus were engulfed by oyster haemocytes during incubation, which were indicated with green fluorescence by using microscope (Fig. 8A) . The phagocytic rate of haemocytes towards V. splendidus in the rHis-CgFREP1 group was about 33.0%, which was significantly 2.02-fold higher (p < 0.01) than that in rTrx group by fluorescence microscope (Fig. 8B) .
body_text.section: The phagocytosis rate of oyster haemocytes after incubation with rHis-CgFREP1

body_text.text: The phagocytosis of haemocytes towards V. splendidus was also detected by flow cytometric analysis (Fig. 8C) . The haemocytes phagocytic rate towards V. splendidus in the rHis-CgFREP1 group was 41.1%, which was significantly 2.48-fold higher (p < 0.01) than that in rTrx group (Fig. 8D ). The raw data were shown in Fig. S2 .
body_text.section: The phagocytosis rate of oyster haemocytes after incubation with rHis-CgFREP1

body_text.text: FREPs constitute a large family of molecules, defined by the presence of an FBG domain. These molecules are found in various animals and are diverse in both structure and function. There are about 190 FREPs with more than 200 FBG domains predicted in the genome of the oyster C. gigas, indicating the expansion and diversification of FREPs in oysters. The large amount of FREPs suggests that they have considerable functional significance in the immune response of mollusc [44] . In the present study, a fibrinogen-like protein (CgFREP1) was identified in C. gigas, which contain a signal peptide and an FBG domain. Previous reports have demonstrated that the FBG domain in FREPs mainly contributes to carbohydrate-binding and pathogen-binding, which make the function of FREPs as PRRs in the innate immune responses [24, 28, 54] . The multiple sequence alignment analysis revealed that the FBG domains of CgFREP include conserved Ca 2+ binding sites. Furthermore, there were potential glycosylation sites in the FBG domain of CgFREP1. The presence of a conserved FBG domain in CgFREP1 might indicate its important role as a PRR in C. gigas. Similar to some other molluscan FREPs, there was no collagen-like region found in CgFREP1, indicating that the FBG domain of FREPs in mollusc plays a vital role in innate immunity. In the phylogenetic tree, CgFREP1 was firstly clustered with CgFCN-1, AiFREP from A. irradians and MgFREP-1 from Mytilus galloprovincialis, and then assigned into the invertebrate branch. These results suggested that CgFREP1 was a member of the FREP family in molluscs.
FREP plays an important role in the innate immunity of invertebrates [55], such as immune recognition, agglutination, and phagocytosis [56] .

In invertebrates, most of FBG-containing proteins are widely distributed in different tissues. In the present study, CgFREP1 mRNA was detected in different oyster tissues, including adductor muscle, hepatopancreas, labial palp, gonad, mantle, gills, and haemocytes, possibly indicating its versatile function in the physiological processes of oysters. This ubiquitous expression pattern of FREPs was also found in some other molluscs. ChFCN was ubiquitously expressed in all the examined tissues, with the highest expression in the gills [9] . MgFREPs from M. galloprovincialis were detected in several tissues, including muscle, mantle, gills, gonads, foot, gland, and haemocytes [9] . In the present study, the highest expression level of CgFREP1 mRNA was found in mantle, gills and labial palp of C. gigas compared to other tissues. The mantle, gills and labial palp act as the first line of molluscs to contact with the complex living environment. The high expression level of CgFREP1 in these tissues suggested that CgFREP1 might play important roles in the response against changing environment. FREPs act as PRRs playing important roles in pathogen recognition in the innate immune response of vertebrates [57] . In human, ficolins can bind to PAMPs through its FBG domain and function as a PRR [7, 31, 58, 59] . In fish, TfFREP2 from T. fasciatus was able to bind V. anguillarum [60] , and BbFREP was able to specifically recognize the PAMPs and bacteria (E. coli and S. aureus) [38] . In the present study, the recombinant CgFREP1 displayed binding activity to LPS, MAN. CgFREP1 also exhibited binding activity to Gram-positive bacteria M. luteus, S. aureus and Gram-negative bacteria V. splendidus, E. coli independent of Ca 2+ . These phenomena tempted us to speculate that the CgFREP1 prefers to recognize some PAMPs. Although the P/N value of rHis-CgFREP1 for binding PGN was less than 2.1, it exhibited binding activity to Gram-positive bacteria, and the potential mechanism remains further investigation. It has been reported that some molluscan FREPs are important PRRs involved in immune response [61] . The binding capability of CgFREP1 to PAMPs and bacteria indicated its important roles in the immune defense of C. gigas.

Increasingly reports have indicated that the FREPs exhibit agglutination activities in invertebrates. In the present study, rGST-CgFREP1 showed obvious agglutination activity to M. luteus, V. splendidus and E. coli in the presence of Ca 2+ . The FBG domains of CgFREP1 contain conserved Ca 2+ binding sites. The Ca 2+ -dependent characteristic of FREP was revealed by the crystal structure of tachylectin 5A, which was similar to Ca 2+ -dependent lectin [4, 17, 62] . Similarly, MrFico1 and MrFico2 in M. rosenbergii could agglutinate bacteria in a Ca 2+ -dependent manner [36] , and AiFREP and AiFREP-2 in A. irradians also displayed Ca 2+ dependent agglutination activity towards different bacteria [30] [31] [32] . These results indicated that FREP displayed agglutination activity to different bacteria and functioned as lectins in the innate immunity [30] [31] [32] , which was similar to ficolins in vertebrates.

In mouse, ficolin aggregates bacteria and leads to enhanced phagocytosis of the aggregated bacteria by peritoneal macrophages [17] . In the present study, CgFREP1 was able to enhance the phagocytic ability of haemocytes towards V. splendidus. The haemocytes are considered as one of the main immune components and play crucial roles in mediating cellular and humoral immunity of invertebrates [63] [64] [65] [66] . Considering that rCgFREP1 displayed the activity to enhance the phagocytic ability of haemocytes, it was concluded that CgFREP1 could mediate the cellular immunity of haemocytes in oyster. Ficolins have the capacity to activate the lectin pathway in innate immunity similar to MBL [67] , which bind to pathogenic bacteria, and combine with MASPs to form C3 complex and promote the cleavage of C3 to generate C3b for mediating cell phagocytosis [68] [69] [70] . In the present study, rCgFREP1 was able to bind the CUB domain of rCgMASPL-1 in vitro, indicating that CgFREP1 may have the same ability to bind MASPs as Ficolin and MBL in vertebrates. Recently, increasing studies have shown that the origin of complement components can be traced back to invertebrates [19, 41, 71] . It was found that amphioxus FCN1 formed complexes with MASP1/3 and facilitated the activation of native C3 protein in humoral fluid [14] . Whether the CgFREP1 can combine with CgMASPL-1 to activate complement lectin pathway in oysters needs further investigation.

In conclusion, a fibrinogen-like protein (CgFREP1) was identified in C. gigas and its functions are similar to mammalian ficolins. The conserved FBG domain in CgFREP1 suggested that CgFREP1 was a primitive member of the FREP family in invertebrates. CgFREP1 exhibited not only binding activity to the PAMPs and bacteria, but also agglutination activity to bacteria in the presence of Ca 2+ . CgFREP1 mediated the phagocytosis of haemocytes towards V. splendidus, and exhibited binding activity to the CUB domain of CgMASPL-1. This work expands our understanding of the functions of FREPs in the innate immune response of oysters and provides inspiration for the evolutionary of molluscan complement pathways.

back_matter.text: We are grateful to all the laboratory members for their technical advice and helpful discussions. This research was supported by grants

FIGREF0.text: The domain characters of CgFREP1. A: Protein domains of CgFREP1 were predicted by SMART (http://smart.embl.de/). B: Complete nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequence of CgFREP1. The nucleotides and amino acids are numbered along the left margin. The signal peptide is marked in blue, and the FBG domain is marked in red. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.) Multiple sequence alignment of CgFREP1 with some FREPs from other species. Consensus sequences of the CgFREP1 are highlighted with black background and are shown below the alignment. The protein sequences of FREP used for sequence alignment analysis are as follows: the fibrinogen-like protein 1 precursor (Homo sapiens NP_004458.3); the fibrinogen C domain-containing protein 1-B-like (Mizuhopecten yessoensis XP_021340650.1); the fibrinogen C domaincontaining protein 1 (Danio rerio XP_005166963.1); the fibrinogen C domain-containing protein 1 isoform X2 (Mus musculus XP_006498531.1); the fibrinogenlike protein 1 (Priapulus caudatus XP_014681173.1); the fibrinogen C domain-containing protein 1-like isoform X1 (Acropora digitifera XP_015772739.1); the ficolin (C. hongkongensis AHY19025.1); the fibrinogen C domain-containing protein 1-like (C. virginica XP_022295252.1).

FIGREF1.text: The phylogenetic tree based on amino acid sequences of CgFREP1 and some other FREPs from invertebrates and vertebrates. The numbers at the forks indicate the bootstrap. The deduced amino acid sequences of FREPs used for phylogenetic analysis are as follows: HsFREP: fibroleukin precursor from H. sapiens (NP_006673.1); TgFLP1: fibrinogen-like protein 1 from Taeniopygia guttata (XP_002191357.2); AcFLP1: fibrinogen-like protein 1-like from Anolis carolinensis (XP_003221685.1); AmFLP1: fibrinogen-like protein 1-like from Ailuropoda melanoleuca (XP_002923835.1); OcFLP1: fibrinogenlike protein 1-like from Oryctolagus cuniculus (XP_002709386.1); MdFLP1: Fibrinogen-like protein 1 from Myotis davidii (ELK37710.1); XlFREP: Fibrinogen like 2 L homeolog precursor from Xenopus laevis (NP_001088488.1); AiFREP: fibrinogenrelated protein from A. irradians (ACB29735.1); MgFREP-1: fibrinogen-related protein 1 from M. galloprovincialis (CBM41040.1); CgFCN-1: Ficolin-1 from C. gigas (EKC25340.1); CgFCN-2: Ficolin-2 from C. gigas (EKC40407.1); CgFREP: Fibrinogen C domain-containing protein 1 from C. gigas (EKC37091.1); CgFREP-A: Fibrinogen-like protein A from C. gigas (EKC41225.1). comparisons using Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS) 22.0 [49]. Statistically significant difference was considered significant at p < 0.05.

FIGREF2.text: The expression level of CgFREP1 mRNA in different tissues of oyster. CgFREP1 mRNA expression level in adductor muscle, hepatopancreas, haemocytes, gills, mantle, gonad and labial palp of oysters were normalized to that of adductor muscle. Each value was shown as mean ± S.D. (n = 3). Different letters: p < 0.05 (one-way ANOVA).

FIGREF3.text: The bacteria and PAMP binding activity of rCgFREP1. A: The bacteria binding activity of rHis-CgFREP1 and rTrx towards different bacteria revealed by western blot. Lane 1: M. luteus; Lane 2: S. aureus; Lane 3: V. splendidus; Lane 4: E. coli. B: ELISA analysis of the interaction between rHis-CgFREP1 and the PAMPs.

FIGREF4.text: The interaction between rCgFREP1 and rCgMASPL-1-CUB1. A: The domain characters of CgMASPL-1. B: SDS-PAGE analysis of rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1. Lane M: protein molecular standard (kDa); Lane 1: negative control for rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1 (without induction); Lane 2: induced rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1; Lane 3: purified protein. C: SDS-PAGE analysis of rGST-CgFREP1. Lane M: protein molecular standard (kDa); Lane 1: negative control for rGST-CgFREP1 (without induction); Lane 2: induced rGST-CgFREP1; Lane 3: purified protein. D: SDS-PAGE analysis of rHis-CgFREP1. Lane M: protein molecular standard (kDa); Lane 1: negative control for rHis-CgFREP1 (without induction); Lane 2: induced rHis-CgFREP1; Lane 3: purified protein. E: The interaction between rGST-CgFREP1 and rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1 were tested by GST Pull-down. Lane M: protein molecular standard (kDa); Lane 1: The purified rGST-CgFREP1; Lane 2: The purified rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1 proteins; Lane 3: washing; Lane 4: The interaction of rGST-CgFREP1 protein with rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1; Lane 5: The purified rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1; Lane 6: The purified rGST-CgFREP1 proteins; Lane 7: washing; Lane 8: The interaction of rHis-CgMASPL-1-CUB1 protein with rGST-CgFREP1. molecular weight of rGST-CgFREP1 and rHis-CgFREP1, respectively.

FIGREF5.text: The agglutination activity of CgFREP1 towards bacteria. The agglutination of rGST-CgFREP1 towards S. aureus, M. luteus, V. splendidus and E. coli was detected in the presence of Ca 2+ . GST was incubated with the bacteria and employed as a negative control.

FIGREF6.text: The phagocytosis activity of oyster haemocytes to the V. splendidus mediated by CgFREP1. A: Phagocytic rate in different treatment by using fluorescence microscope. V. splendidus was labeled by FITC. B: Phagocytosis rate was calculated as follows: (No. of cells ingesting bacteria/No. of cells observed) × 100%. C: Phagocytic rate in different treatment by using flow cytometry. D: Phagocytic rate was shown as mean ± S. D. (n = 3). **: p < 0.01 (Student's t-test).
